columns.text: In this problem, we will deal with a case analysis where we will consider the best case and worst case scenarios for a project.

We can recall that the best case scenario has the production costs and all other fixed costs at a minimum while the sale price and the production quantity are at the maximum. The opposite is true for the worst-case scenario analysis where the production costs and fixed costs take on the max value while the sale price and the production quantity take on the lowest possible value.

In a best-case analysis, the number of units produced and the sale price are highest while all the expenses take on the lowest possible value. 

In this case, the given values are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\$1440\\[15 pt]
\text{Variable cost}&=\$460\\[15 pt]
\text{Fixed cost}&=\$3,900,000\\[15 pt]
\text{Quantity}&=85,000
\end{aligned}$$

To get the values for the **best case scenario**, we need to increase the price and the quantity by $15\%$. To do this, we can simply multiply the values by $1.15$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price (Best-case)}&=\$1440 \times 1.15\\[15 pt]
&=\$1656\\[15 pt]
\text{Quantity (Best-case)}&=85,000 \times 1.15\\[15 pt]
&=97,750
\end{aligned}$$

For the costs, we can multiply these by $100\%-15\%=85\%$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost (Best-case)}&=\$460 \times 0.85\\[15 pt]
&=\$391\\[15 pt]
\text{Fixed cost (Best-case)}&=\$3,900,000 \times 0.85\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,315,000
\end{aligned}$$

For the **worst-case**, we will do the opposite to the values. For the price and the quantity, we will multiply it by $0.85$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price (Worst-case)}&=\$1440 \times 0.85\\[15 pt]
&=\$1224\\[15 pt]
\text{Quantity (Worst-case)}&=85,000 \times 0.85\\[15 pt]
&=72,250\\

\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost and the fixed cost will then be multiplied by $1.15$ to get the worst-case values

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost (Worst-case)}&=\$460 \times 1.15\\[15 pt]
&=\$529\\[15 pt]
\text{Fixed cost (Worst-case)}&=\$3,900,000 \times 1.15\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,485,000
\end{aligned}$$

In conclusion, the best-case scenario values are $\$1656$ for the price, $97,750$ for the quantity, $\$391$ for the variable cost, and $\$3,315,000$ for the fixed cost. 

On the other hand, the worst-case scenario values are $\$1224$ for the price, $72,250$ for the quantity, $\$529$ for the variable cost, and $\$4,485,000$ for the fixed cost.
